Description: Pair statue depicting husband and wife, seated upon a high backed chair, with arms around extended around each others shoulders. The man wears a long white kilt, and is depicted with red skin, while the woman wears a tight-fitting ankle-length white dress; her skin is depicted as light yellow. Both wear elaborate layered wigs. The statue is uninscribed. The sides of the chair are decorated with a scalloped motif, edged on two sides with a decorative border of rectangles.
Curator's comments: Such small pair statues were the focal point for cult in the tomb-chapel; the lower part of a statue of similar scale is still visible in the tomb of Menna at Thebes (TT69). A very similar statue, in scale, form and style, is Museo Egizio 3057 (Turin), of a couple named Pawer and Mut (see Donadoni Roveri, Museo Egizio, p.34).
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1994 Apr-Aug, Museum of St. Albans, Out of Egypt: Every day life in Ancient Egypt
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 2nd Earl of Belmore
